Title: Areopagitica
Notes: Banned in the Kingdom of England for political reasons.

Title: Fanny Hill or Memoirs of a Woman of Pleasure
Notes: Banned in the UK till after the Second World War.

Title: Rights of Man
Notes: Banned in the UK and author charged with treason for supporting the French Revolution.

Title: Despised and Rejected
Author(s): Rose Laure Allatini (under the pseudonym A. T. Fitzroy)
Notes: Banned under the UK's Defence of the Realm Act for criticizing Britain's involvement in World War I, and for sympathetically depicting male homosexuality.

Title: Lady Chatterley's Lover (1928)
Notes: Banned in the United Kingdom for violation of obscenity laws; the ban was lifted in 1960.[clarification needed]

Title: The Well of Loneliness (1928)
Notes: Banned in the UK in 1928 for its lesbian theme; republished in 1949.

Title: Boy
Notes: Proscuted in 1934 after Hanley's publisher Boriswood lost a court case against a charge of obscenity. Reprinted in 1992 by Penguin Books and André Deutsch.

Title: Last Exit to Brooklyn
Notes: Banned in Soho for frank depictions of taboo subjects, such as drug use, street violence, homosexuality, gender identity and domestic violence.

Title: Spycatcher
Notes: Banned in the UK 1985–1988 for revealing secrets. Wright was a former MI5 intelligence officer and his book was banned before it was even published in 1987.

Title: Lord Horror
Notes: Banned in England in 1991 where it was found obscene; it is currently the last book to be banned in the UK. The judge ordered the remaining print run to be destroyed. The ban was lifted in the Appeal Court in July 1992 but the book remains out of print.

Title: The Anarchist Cookbook
Notes: Criminal due to containing information useful to terrorists.

Title: Kill or Get Killed
Notes: Criminal due to containing information useful to terrorists.

Title: Put 'Em Down. Take 'Em Out. Knife Fighting Techniques From Folsom Prison
Notes: Criminal due to containing information useful to terrorists.
